contentrichtext.text: {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2012}} {|{{Infobox ship begin}} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image= |Ship caption= }} {{Infobox Ship Career |Hide header= |Ship country= |Ship flag= {{USN flag|1946}} |Ship name=USS ''Aquamarine'' |Ship namesake= |Ship ordered= |Ship builder=Pusey and Jones Corporation, [[Wilmington, Delaware]] |Ship laid down= |Ship launched=10 April 1926 |Ship acquired=by purchase, 13 January 1941 |Ship commissioned=9 April 1941 |Ship decommissioned=21 June 1946 |Ship in service= |Ship out of service= |Ship struck= |Ship renamed= |Ship reclassified= |Ship homeport= |Ship motto= |Ship nickname= |Ship honors= |Ship fate=Sold into private ownership, 1947 |Ship status= |Ship notes= }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship type= [[Patrol boat]] |Ship tonnage= |Ship displacement= {{convert|194|LT|t|0|abbr=on}} |Ship length= {{convert|124|ft|m|abbr=on}} |Ship beam= {{convert|20|ft|6|in|m|abbr=on}} |Ship draft={{convert|7|ft|m|abbr=on}} |Ship depth= |Ship hold depth={{convert|9|ft|7|in|m|abbr=on}} |Ship propulsion=[[Gasoline]] engines, 1 shaft, {{convert|600|bhp|0|abbr=on}} |Ship speed= {{convert|12|kn|lk=in}} |Ship complement=36 |Ship armament=2 Ã— .30 caliber guns |Ship armor= |Ship notes= {{Infobox NRHP | name = Siele (motor yacht) |embed=yes | nrhp_type = | image = | caption = | location= Tides Inn, Carter Creek, [[Irvington, Virginia]] | lat_degrees = 37 | lat_minutes = 39 | lat_seconds = 48 | lat_direction = N | long_degrees = 76 | long_minutes = 26 | long_seconds = 1 | long_direction = W | locmapin = Virginia | area = | built =1926 | architect= Dobson, B.T.; Pusey & Jones Shipyard | architecture= Other | added = 12 November 1998<ref name="nris">{{NRISref|2008a}}</ref> | governing_body = Private | refnum=98001310 }} }} |} '''USS ''Aquamarine'' (PYc-7)''' was a [[patrol boat]] in the [[United States Navy]] during [[World War II]]. Later known as '''''Miss Ann''''', the ship was listed on the U.S. [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 1998.<ref name="nris"/> ''Aquamarine'' was built in 1925 by [[Pusey and Jones]] Corporation, [[Wilmington, Delaware]] under the name ''Siele'', the private yacht of John H. French. In 1936 she was sold to Robert H. Wolfe, of Columbus, Ohio, and renamed ''Seawolf''.<ref name="nrhpinv2">{{Cite web |title=National Register of Historic Places Registration: Siele (1926-1936) / Sea Wolf (1936-1941); USS Aquamarine (1941-1946); Sea Wolf (1946-1952); Miss Ann (Preferred; 1952-1997); VDHR file# 51-10 |url=http://www.dhr.virginia.gov/registers/Counties/Lancaster/051-0010_Miss_Ann_Yacht_1998_Final_Nomination.pdf |date=1 March 1998 |first=Michael Ashton |last=Raymond |first2=Kindall |last2=Hollingsworth |publisher=Virginia Department of Historic Resources |accessdate=2-12-08-23}}</ref> ''Seawolf'' was bought by the Navy on 13 January 1941, and commissioned on 9 April 1941, Lieutenant G. A. Lange in command. She was named for the [[gemstone]] [[Beryl#Aquamarine and maxixe|aquamarine]]. ==Service history== ===US Navy, 1941–1946=== Assigned to the [[United States Naval Research Laboratory|Naval Research Laboratory]], Bellevue, D.C., ''Aquamarine'' assisted in experimental work, chiefly underwater sound. Although most of her experiments were conducted on the [[Potomac River]] and [[Chesapeake Bay]], she also operated off [[New London, Connecticut]], from 16 October to 4 November 1943, and off the [[Florida]] coast and in the Bahamas from 24 January 1944 to 18 April 1945. During 1945 and 1946 ''Aquamarine'' had additional duty as special tender to the presidential yachts {{USS|Potomac|AG-25|2}} and {{USS|Williamsburg|AGC-369|2}}. ''Aquamarine'' was decommissioned on 21 June 1946 and transferred to the [[Maritime Commission]] on 31 January 1947 for disposal. ===Private ownership, 1947–2008=== She was sold to Colonel E. M. Grimm of Columbus, Ohio, in 1947, and her name changed back to ''Seawolf''. She was sold in 1954 to Ennolls A. Stephens of [[Irvington, Virginia]], owner of [[The Tides Inn]], Irvington, and renamed ''Miss Ann''. In 2008, ''Miss Ann'' was sold to private interests who placed her in Charter Service on the Potomac River. She is currently located at the Colonial Beach Yacht Club in Colonial Beach, Virginia. ==See also== * [[List of patrol vessels of the United States Navy]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} * {{DANFS|http://www.history.navy.mil/danfs/a10/aquamarine.htm}} ==External links== * [http://missanncharters.com ''Miss Ann'' Charters] * [http://www.dhr.virginia.gov/registers/Counties/Lancaster/Siele_MissAnnYacht_photo.htm Virginia Department of Historic Resources] {{DEFAULTSORT:Aquamarine (PYc-7)}} [[Category:Patrol vessels of the United States Navy]] [[Category:1926 ships]] [[Category:Ships on the National Register of Historic Places]] [[Category:National Register of Historic Places in Lancaster County, Virginia]]
